definitions.usage_note: 通常作不可数名词。指皮肤排出的液体，可喻指努力、辛苦。

sentences.en: She wiped the sweat from her brow after the run.
sentences.zh: 跑步后她擦去了额头上的汗。

sentences.en: The room was hot and everyone was covered in sweat.
sentences.zh: 房间里很热，每个人都大汗淋漓。

sentences.en: This project took blood, sweat, and tears to complete.
sentences.zh: 这个项目付出了血汗和泪水才得以完成。

collocations.explain: 因热、紧张或恐惧而sudden sweating

sentences.en: He broke out in a sweat when he heard the news.
sentences.zh: 他听到消息时出了一身汗。

sentences.en: She tried to sweat off the extra pounds at the gym.
sentences.zh: 她试图在健身房通过出汗减掉多余体重。

perspiration.diffs: perspiration 较正式；sweat 更口语

definitions.usage_note: 可及物或不及物。指身体出汗，或物体表面渗出水分；口语中可指努力工作、担心。

sentences.en: He was sweating heavily after the workout.
The cheese was sweating in the warm room.
sentences.zh: 奶酪在温暖的房间里渗出了水分。

sentences.en: We sweated over the exam preparation for weeks.
sentences.zh: 我们为备考苦干了数周。

sentences.en: We just have to sweat it out until the results come.
sentences.zh: 我们只能硬撑到结果出来。

sentences.en: He sweated over the report all night.
sentences.zh: 他整晚都在为这份报告费劲。

perspire.diffs: perspire 较正式；sweat 更常用

sentences.en: She was perspiring lightly after yoga.

etymology.origin: 源自古英语 swāt，与古高地德语 sweiz、拉丁语 sūdor（汗）同源。
etymology.history: 日耳曼语词根，原指体液或汗，经古英语保留至今。

sentences.en: His hands were sweaty from nervousness.

sweatshirt.rule: sweat + shirt，原指运动时穿的上衣

sentences.en: She pulled on a sweatshirt before going out.
sentences.zh: 她出门前套上了一件卫衣。

common_mistakes.explain: sweat 与 sweet 拼写相近易混淆。sweat 为名词/动词“汗；出汗”；sweet 为形容词“甜的”。

mnemonics.content: sweat 与 sweet（甜的）形近，出汗是“咸的”（salty），别搞混。
